awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Algebraic Geometry and Singularities in Positive and Mixed Characteristic
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic Geometry studies algebraic varieties which are geometric objects defined by polynomial equations. One of the most natural problems in this area is to understand the singularities that naturally occur when considering algebraic varieties and how these singularities influence the global geometry of algebraic varieties. In recent years there have been a number of breakthroughs, especially in the case where we consider solutions over the complex numbers. At the same time new techniques and approaches have emerged for studying solutions in positive and mixed characteristics. The primary goal of this collaborative project is to advance and unify these ideas to further understand and solve some of the most challenging programs in both local and global algebraic geometry. In addition the project provides research training opportunities for graduate students.
 
The PIs will investigate singularities in positive and mixed characteristics by using a variety of techniques including those arising from the minimal model program, from the theory of F-singularities, and from Scholze's work on perfectoid algebras and spaces. The PIs will also organize workshops, a summer school and a conference, aimed at training young researchers in this area, disseminating recent results and facilitating further advances and breakthroughs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The projects are focused on questions in singularities in birational geometry and commutative algebra, with a focus in the mixed characteristic case. There are substantial progress on the proposed projects. Together with Schwede and several other coauthors, we systematically use ideas from perfectoid algebras and spaces to study singularities when the varieties are defined over the p-adic integers (this is called the mixed characteristic case). We apply these ideas to established the minimal model program (MMP) for threefolds in mixed characteristic when the residue characteristic is bigger than 5. Roughly speaking, this means for any variety defined over the p-adic integers for p>5, if the dimension is at most three, then we can find a series of birational transforms (divisorial contractions or flips) to arrive at a minimal model or a Mori fiber space. In more recent work, with the same set of authors, we have constructed a test ideal in mixed characteristic via the p-adic Riemann-Hilbert functor of Bhatt-Lurie, this object agrees with multiplier ideal after inverting p, and satisfies the full suite of expected properties of a multiplier ideal. We have used the perfectoidization functor of Bhatt-Scholze to introduce numerical invariants in mixed characteristic in analogy with well-developed numerical invariants in positive characteristic, and have obtained important applications to the finiteness of etale fundamental groups of certain singularities in mixed characteristic.

We have made substantial progress on the study of Hilbert-Samuel multiplicities, which is a classical invariant that measures the singularities of local commutative rings. Our focus is on the long-standing Lech's conjecture: this is simply the conjecture that multiplicities do not decrease under faithfully flat extensions of local rings. One major outcome is that we can prove this conjecture when the base ring is standard graded over a field (previously, the conjecture was only know in dimension at most two or in dimension at most three in the equal characteristic setting). Our strategy is to introduce a sequence of finitely generated modules that asymptotically behaves like Ulrich modules. This turns out to have many other appliations in commutative algebra. In very recent joint work with Iyengar, Walker and Zhuang, we gave a negative answer to a 40-year open question in commutative algebra: that Ulrich modules do not always exist over Cohen-Macaulay rings.

In the past four years, I have been giving several lecture series (three or more hours lectures and mini courses) on positive and mixed characteristic aspects of commutative algebra at various workshops at University of Illinois at Chicago, University of Michigan, (virtually) ICTP, and SLMath. I have also co-organized several workshops and conferenes: one in Oxaca (in a hybrid form), one in Seattle (in person), and one at SLMath. One of my former student at Purdue was funded by the grant under reporting, and he has produced two very nice papers on Hilbert-Samuel and Hilbert-Kunz multiplicities.
